body:
Hello friends & newsletter readers,

Wow! It has been a really long time since I‚Äôve sent out a newsletter. Like, more than half a year. This was for a few reasons; I have been adjusting to my new job, and I also haven‚Äôt had many ‚Äútime-sensitive announcements‚Äù to make.

Well, now it is now, and I actually have several things to share all at the same time! I‚Äôm in two art exhibitions that open this weekend, one in New Haven, CT, and one at Western Michigan University. I am also helping organize a music show in New Haven later this month, featuring two touring electronic musician friends from Worcester, MA. I‚Äôll include the event flyers below; click on them for a link with more info about each one.

Meanwhile, I‚Äôve been chugging along, making stuff, thinking about stuff, and experimenting. Here are some of the things I‚Äôve been up to‚Ä¶

Andrei and I did two performances as REALITY ORP in the fall; one at Weird Music Night at Ely Center in New Haven, and a virtual one for the Internet Archive.

I did a weird art project that involved making my own font!

I‚Äôve continued to make and send out new things regularly for Zine Club. (I‚Äôm actually currently working on a new thing!) I did another reveal post in November to share some new things I made and sent out over the past year.

Andrei and I continued our yearly tradition of visiting Anna Oxygen‚Äôs TV Club Class at Hamilton College.

I made a(nother) deck of cards. This one is a personal index of my ideas, and I wrote about the project on my website.

As usual, I‚Äôve been steadily working on my website. I created a long-overdue links page, a new section called notes, and a 2025 year in review post. (Under the hood, I made it easier to share event invites and upcoming events, and built myself some JavaScript-based GUI tools for editing my website code.)

I also started a project with a friend where we send each other music we make every 2 weeks. I haven‚Äôt shared any of the songs publicly yet, but it‚Äôs been a great thing for getting me to work with sound more.

I‚Äôve continued my weekly work at Faruqee Driscoll Studio. My most interesting tasks recently have included automating the creation of generative graphics, and doing CAD for custom laser-cut steel tools. It‚Äôs been extremely cold for the last month here in New Haven, and like many people in the northeast, we got about 18 inches of snow all at once last week. So‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs that.

Thanks for being on this list, and staying connected with me despite my relative lack of normal social media. Hope you are all doing well. Keep in touch.
subject: PK Newsletter - February 2026 üèîÔ∏è

body:
Hello!

It‚Äôs been a minute since I last wrote a newsletter, so here are some updates!

In the last issue, I was still job searching, and I‚Äôm happy to report that in the meantime, I found and started a new role as a studio assistant for an artist couple who make cool moir√© pattern paintings.

So far it‚Äôs been an interesting gig, and I‚Äôve learned some new things in both physical and digital media to support their work. I am also doing some carpentry and helping build out/maintain their studio, which has inspired me to get back into doing more woodworking projects. (If you‚Äôve been following this newsletter for a while, you may recall my shed project from last year!) I have wood shop access at work, but it‚Äôs ended up being more convenient to use the wood shop at MakeHaven, the local makerspace, since they sell sheets of high quality plywood there and have a wider array of saws.

I‚Äôve also been doing some 3D modeling and CAD in Rhino at my new job, which led to me trying it out for designing objects I‚Äôm making outside work as well. So far, I have enjoyed using Rhino a lot more than other 3D modeling programs I‚Äôve tried, and it has some powerful scripting/automation capabilities that I would like to try using for ‚Äúart‚Äù in addition to these more practical objects.

Also, the people I work for recently got a puppy, so my job has expanded slightly to include helping care for him. His name is Thor, and he is currently four months old and learning about the world.

In more tech-related updates, I had been meaning to get back into journaling more regularly, so I ended up building a simple web app in Python/Flask, and started hosting it on a Raspberry Pi (a small linux computer) located in a corner of my office/studio. It‚Äôs cool to host my own little website and know that every time I use it, I‚Äôm connecting directly to a physical device in my home. Even though it‚Äôs mostly just for my own use (the UI is ideal for casually writing on my phone), anyone can view my public posts at https://journal.palomakop.tv/. The code is also public so theoretically other people can use it to run their own journals as well, if they share my niche desire for a web-based journaling system.

I am continually having new ideas for website improvements and other custom things that I want to build for myself and my friends. Since coding is not the primary focus of my current job (though I have snuck in some Adobe and Rhino automations to streamline processes there), and I‚Äôm usually not already sitting at the computer for most of my day, I think that gives me more mental bandwidth to work on computer-based personal projects during my time off.

Since my last newsletter went out, Andrei and I have performed two live audiovisual sets as REALITY ORP, one at Light & Sound Design in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and one just this past Saturday at ChaNorth Residency Space in Pine Plains, NY. I shared a bit more about both shows on my blog, and below is a short edit of some of the sounds and visuals from our most recent show:

Both shows were really fun and nice opportunities for friends to gather around for strange rituals. I usually try to share more info about events I‚Äôm doing before they happen, but I dropped the ball on that for the most recent one. Hopefully I will do better going forward! To that end, our next show will be Weird Music Night on September 11, at the Ely Art Center in New Haven, CT, 7pm. Our friend Kit is also playing so it should be a great time! Too early for a flyer to exist, but mark your calendar if you‚Äôre one of the approximately 2 people on this list who live in the New Haven area :) It will also be the last Weird Music Night until Ely Center is settled from their upcoming location transition.

Well, that‚Äôs probably enough ‚Äúnews‚Äù for this edition of the newsletter. Be well, and stay in touch.
subject: PK Newsletter - July 2025 üèñÔ∏è

body:
Hi people!

I hope that, if you‚Äôre in the northern hemisphere and sufficiently far from the equator to experience seasons, you are enjoying the spring weather. Here in New Haven, CT, it‚Äôs been raining a lot lately; the upside is that all of the plants are thriving. Whenever it‚Äôs not raining, I‚Äôve been spending as much time as I can outside.

If I‚Äôm being totally honest, while the weather is helping me feel optimistic lately, there has also been a lot of other stuff that is doing the opposite. I have had to make a strong effort to avoid spending more than a few minutes on social media and news feeds per day, or else risk catching a debilitating case of gloom. But even avoiding these things doesn‚Äôt make the job market any better or the cost of basic needs any lower, and it‚Äôs hard to imagine that any of the terrible things going on right now will stop any time soon. Normally I reserve this topic for in-person conversation, but at this point it feels strange not to mention it at all. Thankfully, I also have some exciting and fun things going on as well, so I will share a few of them here. Hopefully they will brighten your day a little too, and help offset the other stuff just a tiny bit.

After my last update in March, I had a very busy spell where I played two shows, taught a workshop, and finished off my six-week batch at Recurse Center ‚Äî along with the coding projects I was working on during that time. Afterwards, I managed to gather a bit of documentation about each of these things on my blog.

I also made a short 2 minute cut of some footage from my show at Union Docs:

Lastly, I wrote a bit about the projects I worked on at Recurse Center in depth on my blog, but the two main things were:

And:

I had a very fun and productive time during my retreat at RC, and have kept in touch with some folks from the community there. But it was also a bit intense! So after finishing all of these things, I tried to take a bit of a break.

In April, I resumed working on freelance projects, mainly building websites and running AV tech for events. (I still have some availability for freelance website and coding work ‚Äî if you need anything, get in touch!) I am still hoping to find more long-term employment soon, and have been throwing all of my spare energy towards that, but I haven‚Äôt had much luck yet. So I‚Äôll just keep stitching various things together for now. (It is really not a great time(/economy) to be job searching in; solidarity to anyone else who‚Äôs in that boat right now.)

I also took some time to expand and improve my own website. I added a sidebar for desktop and a hamburger menu for mobile, which enabled me to add more pages to the main navigation. I also renamed my ‚Äúwork‚Äù section to ‚Äúart‚Äù and created a new section called ‚Äúcode‚Äù to house a portfolio of my coding and web projects.

If you haven‚Äôt seen my website in a while, I invite you to give it a visit and poke around a little!

https://palomakop.tv

Lastly, another thing I‚Äôve been excited about lately is that I gained access to the silkscreen facilities at MakeHaven, my local makerspace. I don‚Äôt want to share photos yet, in case anyone is on here that hasn‚Äôt received theirs yet, but I did my first print run and sent them out to members of the Zine Club Mystery Object tier. I look forward to doing some more silkscreen printing and maybe making some patches or T shirts!

All right, that‚Äôs probably enough for now. Thanks for reading this, keep in touch, and I wish you well.
subject: PK Newsletter - May 2025 üå∫

body:
Hello again friends,

It‚Äôs only been about a month since my last update, but I wanted to send another short one because I have some fun things coming up to share.

I‚Äôm just over halfway through my six-week batch at Recurse Center, which I‚Äôve been attending sometimes in person in Brooklyn and sometimes remotely from New Haven. I am really enjoying it; the community is very inclusive and there are always lots of people to have interesting conversations with. I started out with building a little interactive website called The Lab, but now I am working on building a full-stack web app that lets you pull tarot cards virtually. I‚Äôm learning some more ‚Äúmodern‚Äù1 web development techniques that will hopefully be useful to me in the future.

Later this week, I‚Äôm teaching a workshop at a cool event at Temple University in Philly called Low Tech Electronics Faire. My workshop is already filled up, but there will be lots of other cool things there, and most if not all of them are free to attend. You can find more info on the event website: https://sites.temple.edu/efaire/schedule-and-registration/

I also have two shows coming up, both in NYC near the end of March. The first one is Sunday March 23 at the Living Gallery in Brooklyn, where I‚Äôll be doing an AV collab with Lee Tusman. See the flyer for more details:

The second one is on Sunday March 30th at Union Docs in Ridgewood, Queens. I‚Äôll be playing a solo AV set along with some other excellent experimental/ambient performers.

That‚Äôs all I‚Äôve got for now. Hope you are all doing all right, wherever you are. Until next time‚Ä¶

  1. I called them ‚Äúmodern‚Äù because, compared to plain HTML/CSS they are more recent, and can be more powerful in some ways, but can still be quite antiquated and convoluted in the context of a field that evolves quickly and introduces breaking changes at every turn.
subject: PK Newsletter - March 2025 üì°

body:
Hello again friends,

There are an unexpectedly large number of things going on right now for me. Since my last update, I‚Äôve finished settling into our new apartment in New Haven, and my new studio/office is very nice.

So‚Ä¶ I left my full-time job in 2023 to travel and be self-employed, and now, almost two years later, it turns out that I feel ready to return to a more ‚Äúnormal‚Äù job again. I started polishing up my resum√© and created an account on LinkedIn (something I have resisted doing for a long time).

Well, it turns out that my resistance was justified, because LinkedIn is, in fact, an extremely hellish platform. Within a couple days of joining, I managed to get my new account banned twice until I figured out that some software I run for online privacy was making them think I was a bot. (That has since been resolved, but it didn‚Äôt exactly inspire confidence.)

It‚Äôs been a while since I undertook this type of job search, so if anyone has any recommendations or advice, or if you know someone who is hiring, please get in touch. I‚Äôm especially looking for jobs in software development/IT, and I‚Äôm in New Haven but can make it to NYC fairly easily. I published a resum√© page on my website, feel free to share it if you want to.

Also, if you use LinkedIn as well, please feel free to connect with me there and we can ‚Äúendorse‚Äù each others‚Äô ‚Äúskills.‚Äù At least until I get banned again!

In semi-related news, I am excited to be attending a 6-week coding retreat at Recurse Center. I‚Äôve heard a lot about their program from friends that have attended, so I‚Äôm looking forward to finally getting to participate myself. It‚Äôs sort of like an artist residency, but for computer programming instead of art. (Although you can also make art if your art consists of coding computer programs.) You can work on whatever projects you decide, and collaborate with others who are doing the same. The goals are to improve your coding skills and challenge yourself to try new things, while also building community, and they can also help connect you with job openings.

Since I‚Äôve been obsessively building websites for the past couple of years, I‚Äôm planning to channel that energy into making some interactive web-based experiments and pushing myself beyond my current comfort zone of fully static HTML/CSS. The session I‚Äôm attending starts in just over a week! I‚Äôll be heading into their Brooklyn-based hub for some of it, and doing the rest remotely.

What else is going on? I‚Äôm teaching an HTML/CSS weekend intensive workshop at Wavefield in Brooklyn on March 8-9. If you‚Äôre in the area and want to learn how to build websites from scratch, or you already know how to and just need some external motivation to get you to actually do it, consider joining! If it‚Äôs anything like the online version of this class I did last year, it should be really fun. I can‚Äôt wait to see what people make.

Tickets via Wavefield on Withfriends

Aside from those things, I joined an awesome Makerspace in New Haven and am looking forward to using some of their extensive array of tools to make my next batch of Mystery Objects for Zine Club. I also started doing a work-trade at a local yoga studio. There are a lot of cool things in New Haven!

I have more things coming up in March that I‚Äôm excited to share, but they are still in the cocoon stage of being organized, so I‚Äôll probably send out another update early next month. In the meantime, be well.
subject: PK Newsletter - February 2025 üì°

body:
Hello Friends,

It‚Äôs been a few months. I‚Äôm writing from a new apartment in New Haven, CT. As of a few days ago, Andrei and I have moved out of our temporary yurt residence and into what we hope will be a more long-term situation. The biggest highlight for me is once again having my own private room to dedicate to studio and workspace. This is something I haven‚Äôt really had since I left Brooklyn in spring 2023, and I‚Äôve missed it dearly, so I now appreciate it a lot more. While the prospect of paying something closer to a normal* amount for rent is slightly daunting, I have decided that the tradeoff of not having to constantly uproot myself is worth it.

* ‚ÄùNormal‚Äù for the US in this era of ridiculously inflated living costs.

In other news, I finished up my semester teaching two sections of Intro to Animation as a temporary adjunct at Hamilton College. I really enjoyed the experience of teaching, and I hope to find more opportunities to do so in the future.

In the meantime, since I‚Äôm no longer occupied with teaching classes, I‚Äôm very much available and eager for more freelance projects and commissions! If you or anyone you know needs a website, video/graphics, or other types of things that are up my alley, please let me know!

Other things I‚Äôve been working on include extensive updates to my website. I‚Äôve added a bunch of past work to the /work page on my site, and I also fleshed out my long-neglected MFA page with photos of my thesis book and an index of my thesis work. And there are still more website updates I want to do. I have decided to add a new section for client work and commissions to my main website, instead of having a separate website for my ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù portfolio (which I‚Äôve not-coincidentally been procrastinating working on). After all, the line can be blurry; there are already some things I got paid to do on the /work page mentioned above, and I strive to make work I‚Äôm creatively proud of whether it‚Äôs for a client or myself.

I‚Äôve also continued making physical and digital objects for Zine Club. It‚Äôs been a fun challenge to come up with new and unusual things to send out for each edition; the most recent favorite of these was a ‚Äúuseless‚Äù printed circuit board design. I also updated the webpage with photos of past objects (all sent long enough ago to avoid spoiling them), and added a few testimonials, courtesy of some club members!

It‚Äôs a new year, and I published a Year in Review post on my website. It was a bit trippy looking back and thinking, ‚ÄúThat was all still just this year?‚Äù Time is weird. And times are weird. Thanks for keeping in touch with me via this newsletter, and until next time, take care.
subject: PK Newsletter - January 2025 ‚ùÑÔ∏è

body:
Hello Friends,

This feels like a weird time to be breaking my hiatus from sending newsletter updates. I and many of my friends in the US are still mentally processing the events of the election and how they will continue to play out in the coming years. But of course, we need to continue with the work that we have cut out for us, and supporting the pockets of creativity, community, and empowerment that will continue to keep us going through whatever else is going on in the world.

It‚Äôs been even longer than usual between updates from me for a few reasons. Firstly, I was working hard on rebuilding my artist website using a tool called Eleventy. My site is still coded from scratch, but using this tool allows me to update and edit everything much more easily compared working directly with HTML files. While this was in progress, I didn‚Äôt make any new blog posts for a long time, since they would have just added to the things I had to migrate‚Ä¶ But now, after a few months of chugging away on it in my spare time, I‚Äôm happy to say that the new version is now live! Some things are similar to the old site, but there are a lot of subtle improvements. I invite you to come visit my new site and poke around: https://palomakop.tv/

In particular, consider checking out the new version of the blog ‚Äî I‚Äôve just added some belated posts about shows and things that I did in late summer. https://palomakop.tv/blog/

Another reason I have been a bit quieter than usual is that I was last-minute hired for the semester as an adjunct professor of animation at Hamilton College, which is a few hours north of me, near Utica. I have been driving back and forth each week and teaching two sections of Intro to Animation. This is my first time teaching at a college, and I have been enjoying it a lot. I often think about the professors I had in college who introduced me to so many interesting new things and expanded my world, and it makes me want to help pass that forward to my students.

Meanwhile, as of September, Andrei and I have taken up temporary residence in a yurt near Saugerties, NY. We will be here until the end of the year, when we plan to look for a more permanent space of some kind. After being quite mobile for a year and a half, we are ready to settle in somewhere and set up proper studio/work spaces. But in the meantime, yurt existence is quite cozy.

I‚Äôve continued to send out bimonthly mystery objects and quarterly e-zines for Zine Club, which has slowly been accruing new members; there are now 25. The latest mystery object that I can share (since it was sent out long enough ago that it‚Äôs no longer a mystery) was a handmade set of mysterious cards based on the life cycle of a fictional plant.

At the end of the newsletter, I usually write a bit about events and things I have coming up, but to be honest, I don‚Äôt have anything like that going on right now. I will quietly continue teaching my classes, making zines and objects, doing miscellaneous freelance projects, and figuring out how and where I want to live. I guess the only thing I ask is, let‚Äôs keep in touch. Let me know what you‚Äôre up to. Let‚Äôs keep making art and being there for each other.

Until next time, take good care however you can.
subject: PK Newsletter - November 2024 üçÇ

body:
Hello friends,

It‚Äôs been a few months since my last update, and the time has seemingly flown by. I‚Äôm still here in Upstate NY, doing my best to slowly carve out space to live and work on a small budget so I can spend more time on creative things and in nature. Currently, this has taken the form of sleeping in a small, semi off-grid cabin in the woods, and working on fixing up a small barn (which long ago was home to a pony) on my family‚Äôs property to transform it into an art studio.

Besides playing with power tools and hanging out in the forest, I‚Äôve also been doing some art things. In May, Andrei and I performed a characteristically wacky set as Reality Orp at the Psychic Garden in Rochester. The stars magically aligned and we managed to record decent audio and video of the full set, so it‚Äôs now up on Youtube and Peertube!

I also sent out the first Mystery Object & Quarterly E-zine for my new Zine Club project. (Some of you were on the receiving end!) There are now 18 total Zine Club members, which is pretty cool. I quite enjoyed creating both the physical object (3 vinyl stickers this time) and the virtual zine, which I provided as both a downloadable DRM-free PDF and an online 3D skeuomorphic reading experience (see GIF below). So far, the goal of Zine Club ‚Äî which is to support weird art ‚Äî seems to be working in two ways: it provides me with a small but regular supplementary income, and creates a framework of formats and loose deadlines that helps make me actually do things. I hope to keep this project going for a while! More about Zine Club: palomakop.tv/zine-club

I‚Äôve also continued working on projects for Moon Ark Studio, which has lately been creating websites for friends‚Äô projects and organizations. I am also hoping to take some time to overhaul my own websites as well; the Moon Ark site needs a ‚Äúdesign portfolio,‚Äù and I want to make my artist website easier to update. I can‚Äôt express how much better it feels to put my tech skills to use for actual people, instead of a corporation. (Not to mention much more fun.)

üîú Upcoming Things

In July, Andrei and I will be taking another road trip in our 1988 camper van. But it will be much shorter and chiller than last year‚Äôs 5-month, 7000-mile adventure (which ended up being too much for me‚Ä¶) We‚Äôll be traveling around the midwest, starting with an artist residency & workshop in Iowa City, and some vague plans in other places including Champaign-Urbana, Kansas City, and Minneapolis. (If anyone reading this is in the Iowa City area, join our workshop on July 6!)

Well, that‚Äôs probably enough for now; more updates whenever I end up writing them. As always, thank you so much for being a part of this newsletter and helping me stay in touch outside of corporate social media platforms.

Until next time, be well.
subject: PK Newsletter - June 2024 üåû

body:
Hi friends,

It's been almost two months since my last update, and I'm still house-sitting here in Upstate New York. Much has occurred since my last newsletter went out; I did an artist talk at Luck Dragon in Delhi, NY, went on a 7-day silent retreat at IMS, acquired a canine hiking buddy, taught an online HTML/CSS class, and was generally quite busy. I guess I assumed that being tucked away in the woods would be more quiet and peaceful, but at the same time I'm quite happy that we've found lots of interesting things to do that don't involve going into a large city.

Upcoming Things

Zine Club

I have some things to announce! First off, encouraged by positive responses from my last email, I decided to go ahead with my "zine subscription" idea. However, I realized that doing it through Patreon would result in being somewhat locked into their ecosystem, so I found an alternative: running subscriptions directly through Stripe, and creating a page on my own website with all the info. After finally getting everything set up, I am pleased to present... ZINE CLUB!

If you're interested in receiving mysterious virtual and/or physical objects, and supporting weird art, here is the link to check it out: https://palomakop.tv/zine-club/

Intro to Video Feedback at Luck Dragon

On Saturday, April 13, I'll be returning to Luck Dragon, an art supply store and community space in Delhi, NY, to teach a workshop on analog video feedback with Phase Shift Collective. More info here: https://luckdragon.space/event/video-feedback.html

Video Feedback with Cameras - Online Course

There are still a couple slots open for my Video Feedback with Cameras course on Polyphase Portal, which starts this coming Tuesday, March 12 (which is coming up very soon as I write this email, but this class is a bit of an experiment, since I haven't taught this sort of thing online before; if it works out well, I hope to offer it again at some point!) More info here: https://polyphaseportal.xyz/video-feedback-with-cameras/

Past Things

Here are some things I've been up to since my last email.

I did a collaborative performance with modular musician Matthew Ryals at The Avalon in Catskill, NY...

Andrei and I did a Phase Shift video installation at a dying mall in Ithaca, NY for an event hosted by Anna Oxygen...

We also led a Phase Shift video art workshop at The Psychic Garden in Rochester, NY...

Silvering Toward Invisible, a group exhibition I'm in, opened in Portland, Maine...

More writing and images about those things is on the "News" section of my website, which I just finally finished updating with the things I've done so far this year. Keeping my site updated can be tricky; the more things I'm doing, the more updates I get queued up, and the less time I have to actually post them. But I'm hoping to slow down on doing events and such for a bit, so I can have more time in the studio, and more time to chill, in the near future.

My first online HTML/CSS course through Polyphase Portal is now over, and it went really well. I enjoyed sharing my methods and making mistakes live in the screen-share, showing the messy process behind creating hand-coded websites. It was also super cool to see all the participants' websites come together. I am definitely planning to do it again at some point.

Lastly, website, design, and video work for clients of Moon Ark Studio continues! Once I finish the current round of projects, I'm hoping to take some time to put together a portfolio of what we've done so far, to share what I've been up to and provide examples to inspire future clients. If you ever need my creative or technical services, feel free to get in touch!

That's it for now, until I send out another newsletter in a month, or two, or three... Thank you for staying in touch with me in this way, and helping me avoid corporate-owned social media platforms!

Until next time, be well.
subject: PK Newsletter - March 2024 üçÑ

body:
Hello friends!

With the new year comes some new updates on how this newsletter is run. My old method of BCC'ing everyone was getting too unwieldy, so I decided to bite the bullet and start using a "professional" email newsletter service (the one I chose is called Buttondown). I also have a new email address that's connected to the domain of my website: paloma@palomakop.tv. Hopefully everything should work the same from your end! If this email reached your inbox successfully, it would be really nice if you could drop a quick reply that you received it; then I'll know they didn't all go straight into spam or something :)

I'm still in Upstate New York, and it's pretty cold and snowy here right now. I caught a case of covid shortly after New Year's, but luckily it was pretty mild. Other than that, I'm just enjoying having a proper workspace again, for both my computer work and audiovisual experiments!

A lot has been brewing since my last update in November... Here are some things I have coming up:

Presentation at 'Sound'

This Friday, I'll be one of two presenters at a monthly event called Sound, in Delhi, NY. The venue is Luck Dragon, a craft supply store and community space. Hopefully I will meet some new local artists and experimental musicians there! More info at https://luckdragon.space/

Two Online Classes

Coming up in February/March/April, I'll be teaching two online workshops through Polyphase Portal! They are each a series of 4 weekly sessions, intended for realtime virtual participation.

Making Fun, Simple Websites with Handwritten HTML/CSS - February 13-March 5

An introductory course on working directly with HTML and CSS code. So simple, so beautiful, so fun ‚Äî as the internet should be. Join us and build your own page on the world wide web!

More info / register: https://polyphaseportal.xyz/2023/11/20/making-fun-simple-websites-with-handwritten-html-css/

Intro to Video Feedback with Cameras - March 12-April 2

This class will be a bit of an experiment ‚Äî similar to our in-person workshops where we work with camera feedback, but taking place all online. All participants will need to have their own video equipment setups (minimum: 1 video camera with live composite output, and 1 video monitor/screen with composite input).

More info / register: https://polyphaseportal.xyz/2023/11/20/intro-to-video-feedback-with-cameras/

Recent Things

A track of mine was included in Elmet Brae, a lovely ambient compilation by members and friends of the Merveilles.town online community. More info here.

I wrote a Year in Review post on my website for the first time.

I worked on websites and commissions for Moon Ark Studio! I still have some slots open for more projects in the near future; get in touch if you need a website, video, graphic, or some other type of creative or technological assistance!

I got to draw some nice machines for a design project for Andrei:

I redesigned my Now Page, and made some little hand-drawn icons for it. This is a page where I can share what I'm up to and some currently relevant links, updated weekly-ish.

I made some zines over the holidays to give out to friends, and it was very fun. I'm thinking of starting a subscription thing through Patreon where you can sign up to receive a new print or zine or sticker every month or every 2 months. If this is something you'd be interested in, let me know, that will help me decide to go ahead with it!

I'll be on a meditation retreat from February 2-9 in rural Massachusetts, and will be unreachable during that time. I'm looking forward to taking some quiet time/space. Other than that, between upcoming classes, freelance projects, art-making, and house-sitting duties, I seem to have my work cut out for me. I am wishing you a good 2024 and hope that you are staying cozy if it's cold where you are (or staying cool if it's hot)!

Until next time, be well.
